Hi all,

It's really great we can have this conversation here.

While I agree that papers with few results and very good ideas should be
published occasionally, I don't think things should be made easier. Indeed,
Ken, you are the living proof that one can publish novel ideas with
qualitative results only(*) and, though getting such papers accepted may be
frustrating, it is the price to pay to avoid getting *any* random ideas
published. However, look at the benefit: once accepted, how many works have
been following the original idea of novelty search or CPPN?

Moreover, let's keep in mind that for a conference/journal, there are
several reviewers per paper, and then it is up to the editor or
track/conference chair to check reviews for inconsistent or controversial
papers, and ask for complementary reviews if needed -- As an example with
the GECCO 2013 ALIFE track, we provided at least 5 reviews per paper, and
up to 7 for controversial papers. ie. decisions end up as the results from
the combined work of individual reviewers and editors, rather than being
not just be numerical sum&averaging. In the end, a rejected paper may be so
because it has failed to convince the majority of reviewers, would it be
because it is too weak or out of topic wrt. the conference/journal, but
definitely not because a single reviewer killed the paper.

Of course, the fact that canonical, syntactically-correct, papers with
quantitative results are more likely to get accepted is not a good thing
either. If you look at the vast number of publications per year in our
field, there is already quite some noise (ie. papers that will be forgotten
for good or bad reasons), and few papers are actually used to inspire new
research in the years after - which can be seen more or less as an a
posteriori relevant evaluation of a paper's contribution.

It seems to me that the problem is not about accepting more or less papers
with or without qualitative results only, but about leaving more room/time
to presentation and discussion around novel works, would they be with
quantitative or qualitative results -- On the one hand, the current oral
presentation format in conferences, IMHO, partly fail to provide this
space: leaving 5 minutes for question is a bit ridiculous IMHO. On the
other hand, the poster sessions in most AI/EC conferences often leaves me
very frustrated (2 hours for more than one hundred posters, combined with a
social event), with the very notable exception of the PPSN conference
(Parrallel Problem Solving from Nature). At PPSN, there are only posters: a
conference chair (who read your paper) does approx. 3 minutes personal
presentation/interpretation for a dozen of posters, and then you have ~2
hours to wander around and visit posters, which often leads to you
selecting 2-3 posters (There are several such sessions a day, in sequential
order, without any particular topic for a session). The time for discussion
is therefore significant enough to have a true scientific interaction.

A decent poster session with a lower selection rate (~50%? unlike PPSN)
would possibly enable to take some risks with accepting contributions, and
giving anyone the opportunity to present new ideas, without removing the
fact that if you want to get your work accepted for a conference talk or a
journal publication (with high selection rate), you have to work hard to
convince reviewers and editors (as it is already the case for many
journals). To some extent, this is already done elsewhere, for example in
the annual meeting of the Society for Neuroscience (thousands of
attendants, many many posters, keynote talks).

Best,

Nicolas


(*) don't get me wrong, you also published many very good papers with
quantitative results ;-)





2013/4/22 Julian Togelius <julian@...>
